1473096235687063560.text:
Q. How will it protect against natural disasters?
A. We're investing $50B to protect our infrastructure from extreme weather. We know that the dramatic increase in extreme weather events is due in large part to climate change & everything in this bill is aimed at addressing it.

1473095727274418184.text:
Q. How will it help my people like my 81-year-old mother with heating costs?
A. This law includes $$ for energy & cost-saving programs, like $3.5B for the Weatherization Assistance Program, which helps families protect their homes against weather & optimize energy efficiency.

1473095503831347206.text:
Q. Will this bill expand internet access?
A. Yes! MA will receive at least $100M to provide broadband coverage across the state and 19% of people in our state will be eligible for a new benefit that will help low-income families afford internet access.

1473092532699643907.text:
Q. What provisions in the law will increase the ability for people to charge their EV?
A: The #InfrastructureLaw includes $7.5B to build a national network of EV chargers to facilitate long-distance travel and provide convenient charging options. MA will receive $63 million! 🚘

1473091389001027584.text:
Q. How will the law address lead pipes & PFAS?
A: The law provides $55B to ensure clean, safe drinking water is a right in all communities:
-$15B to boost lead pipe remediation efforts around the country
-$1B for MA water infrastructure
-$10B to eliminate & detect PFAS

1473089863943602180.text:
Q. How will we train workers for these new jobs?
A: The #InfrastructureLaw allocates $405M in grants to colleges & universities to develop the next generation of transportation professionals. We're investing in our young people to take on the millions of new jobs we're creating.

1473088353767677955.text:
It’s my job to ensure that you have what you need to be safe today & have a successful tomorrow.
The #InfrastructureLaw will send MA:
-$4B for highway repair
-$1B for bridge replacement & repairs
-$3B to improve public transportation

If a child does become sick, will the entire classroom be sent home or just that one kid?

Thanks all for tuning in! Bottom line: #childcare providers were hurting before (low wages, impossibly high costs for families) & now they're at their breaking point. 

We need to act now: We must pass the #ChildCareisEssentialAct & create a system that works for all families.

1267827820413087746.text: Sharon (@BostonABCD ): The early childhood care & development system is one of the most complicated to reopen, but also one of the most under-resourced. Yes, every business is important but our economy can't operate w/o child care. #childcareisessential

1267826276523372544.text:
Kenaya (@SEIU509 member): Working as a home daycare provider during this time can be very challenging. A lot of the parents and employees I deal w/ have respiratory issues.

I have to weigh my children’s safety against my income. And I miss my children, my babies! 💔

1267825207734984707.text: Ardith: 50% of after school programs we reached out to said they don’t think they’ll be able to reopen. What we need is financial support. What we need is the #ChildCareisEssentialAct. #childcare

1267825206468309002.text: Ardith (@MAPafterschool): The bank we used for our organization to apply for the #PayrollProtectionProgram was difficult to navigate. I can imagine the struggles for individual child care providers trying to apply through that program...

Amy O'Leary (@EarlyEd4All): Pre-#COVID19, even at full enrollment, the #childcare system was broken.
